323.name: Number of people living in extreme poverty (OWID based on World Bank (2016) and Bourguignon and Morrisson (2002))
323.description: World population living in extreme poverty
323.datasetName: World Poverty in absolute numbers - OWID based on World Bank (2019) and Bourguignon and Morrisson (2002)
323.s_name: World Poverty in absolute numbers - OWID based on World Bank (2019) and Bourguignon and Morrisson (2002)

source.name: World Poverty in absolute numbers - OWID based on World Bank (2019) and Bourguignon and Morrisson (2002)
source.dataPublishedBy: Max Roser based on World Bank and Bourguignon and Morrisson (2002).
source.dataPublisherSource: The absolute number of the world population is taken from the OurWorldInData world population data set: https://ourworldindata.org/world-population-growth. All poverty estimates 1981 and later are taken from the World Bank's Povcal Net: iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/ (downloaded in February 2019). All data from 1980 and earlier is taken from Bourguignon and Morrisson (2002) – Inequality Among World Citizens: 1820–1992. In American Economic Review, 92, 4, 727–748. Bourguignon and Morrisson (2002) state that 'the poverty lines were calibrated so that poverty and extreme poverty headcounts in 1992 coincided roughly with estimates from other sources’; here I rely on the midpoint of the two series published by Bourguignon and Morrison.
source.additionalInfo: People are considered to live in extreme poverty when living on less than 1.90 international-$ per day. International $ are adjusted for price differences between countries and for price changes over time (inflation).
